Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 09:07PM lrr4993 wrote: Cool - I bought it on line at celebrity style wigs (I think that was the name).   It was a special order - the ones that are made to the measurements of your head. You also can specify amount of hair, baby hairs or not,layered or not, etc.  It feels like almost nothing on.  Much more comfortable than the cap wigs, although those do not bother me tremendously.  It is definitely less itchy, if that was a problem for you.  Also less tight (no elastic used to hold it on) and more light feeling.  It is literally hair sewn into a fine lace - almost as light as super sheer panty hose.  It took about 7 weeks to get it because of the special order.  Now that I think about it, I think that is why it was my second wig - I waited until too late the first time and had to go with a premade one.  By the time I got it my hair was just starting to grow . . a little stubble.  I stopped wearing it when my hair got to about 1 inch long because I was having a horrible time with the glue matting my hair at the temples.  The glue is the downside to me - I really did not like having to deal with it. But I did get pretty good at it after a few weeks.  I still wear it on occassion though.  It stays on better than the caps because the glue is really strong (I used the 1-3 day glue daily . . . there are glues that last for weeks but I never tried them). The other wigs I have had are the Jon Reneu "isabella" wig.  Human hair.  Gorgeous.  Is a cap, but is a relatively thin one.  It was my first wig.  I moved away from it because it started getting tight as my hair grew in and it was starting to thin a bit too much.  I recently wore it again and loved it so much (don't know why it felt more comfortable this time) that I just ordered a new one. I got tons of compliments from complete strangers on how pretty my hair was when I wore this.  And the nurses at my cancer center could not believe it was a wig.  They said it was the most natural wig they had ever seen and even wrote down the name to tell other patients about. I have also tried a raquel welch wig (current one until new one arrives) - can't remember the name of it right now.  another human hair one that I like mainly because it came styled the way I like and it has a bit of natural curl like my own hair.  But the hair quality is not nearly as good as the jon reneau.  Wig.com sells both and if you keep an eye on their site, they run 25% off special regularly.  These are expensive wigs, so that discount is significant.  The lace wig was considerably less than the other two, but still pretty pricey as I recall.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 03:59PM lrr4993 wrote: This happened to me on my second infusion.  It is not as bad as your mind is making it.  I too was scared to death about that.  I read about it here, so I asked that the infusion be titrated.  My chemo nurse told me that they are instructed not to titrate unless there is a documented reaction, so they would not have done so but for me asking.  Be sure you ask if you are worried about this.  I had no problem with the first one. The second time my onco actually ordered the titration to make sure I had no problems with getting it (she really worked hard to calm all my fears, even though she was not worried about it).  I don't know why, but I did react the second time.  I first noticed a general weird feeling - I cannot describe it any better than that.  I just felt weird.  I knew from reading here that the reaction causes breathing problems, so I tried to breathe in deeply once I noticed the weird feeling. . . my chest felt very full or tight with a deep breath.  I knew immediately what was happening and told my mom to get the nurse.  They turned off the drip immediately but not before I started having a pain in my back.  Then it went away.  The whole thing lasted maybe 1-2 minutes. It really was not horrible, although it scared the hell out of  my mom, who was not as prepared for it as I was.  I could breathe fine, I just could not take deep breaths.  The back pain was certainly noticeable, but not unbearable at all.  I would guess that it gets worse the longer you let it go, so call the nurse as soon as you notice it.  I read here to pinch the drip line while waiting for the nurse, although I did not think to do that at the time.   Some people get benadryl or something else when they have a reaction.  I did not.  They just started it slower and I was fine. The downside is that the slower infusion takes about twice a long to do.  Mine took anywhere from 2 - 3 hours depending on how much I pushed them up on the dosage when I got impatient. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Reaction to Taxotere during infustion? Trisha-Anne DiDel

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 07:27PM lrr4993 wrote: Trisha - Please don't be too scared.  I know some people have bad experiences with taxotere and a lot of those are discussed here.  I was terrified going into my first treatment.  It turns out I worried over nothing.  I had very little in the way of SEs (not counting hair loss) and what I did have was short lived and very manageable . . . like a mild flu . . . tired and achey for about 24 hours.  My SEs did not get worse with each tx and, in fact, the last one was the easiest and all were surprisingly easy.  My last tx was at the end of nov and once I got past my usual "mild flu" day, I was fine and back to normal with no lingering problems.  And my hair is growing back quicker than I thought it would.   I know a lot of people have bad experiences, but a lot do fine on it as well.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Reaction to Taxotere during infustion? Trisha-Anne DiDel

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 11:00AM lrr4993 wrote: I have naturally curly hair and consider myself a bit of an expert by virtue of trial and error over a lifetime of trying to control the frizz. Best hair product I have tried so far is Fekkai Glossing creme. Sephora carries it. If you need something less expensive, pantene makes a good defrizzant - don't remember the name but it comes in a small glass bottle with a pump top. Pantene "women of color" shampoo/conditioner line is fabulous for moisturizing and softening curly hair. I also strongly recommend a good hairdryer. Chi hairdryers are the best in my experience. They are expensive, but provide a noticeable difference in smoothing the hair when drying with a round brush.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 01:14PM lrr4993 wrote: Congratulations on your new job!  That is very exciting. I agree with the others.  Just tell them you have a monthly doctors appointment if you need to.  Whoever said cancer equals higher insurance premiums is exactly correct.  My old firm (run by some very nice people) hired a woman who had a significant disability that she hid during interviews (not saying you hid anything, but she did).  She showed up the first day at work with a walker that she did not have in interviews and within a couple of months needed major back surgery.  They were furious and the second she gave them a non-medical reason to be fired, she was. I am sure they are very nice people and I know there are laws that prevent discrimination on issues like this, but it happens nonetheless.  With the market as competitive as it is right now, you do not want to give them any reason to reconsider you.  Even nice people do not like taking on employees who may drive up the costs of business.  Sorry if that sounds harsh.  I don't mean it to be.  I just think you need to be careful.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 05:42PM lrr4993 wrote: This all reminds me of a man I worked for years ago right after getting out of college.  He was an older and very distinguished southern gentlemen - would NEVER say anything offensive.  He and a younger female executive were carrying on one day joking around with each other.  The woman said something smart ass to him.  He responded - and I know he meant it in good humor -  "Laura, you are such a twat."  TWAT.  He meant TWIT.  Laura had the most shocked look on her face.  The rest of us in the room just cracked up.  The man was all confused, at which point my good friend went up to him and whispered in his ear what a twat is - he turned beet red.  I felt so bad for him.  But it was so damn funny.
Posts.Title: Just Need to Wank sbelizabeth autism_mom

Posts.Content: lrr4993 wrote: After a day of crying yesterday, I am obsessing today over every little word the radiologist said in my ultrasound yesterday.  I did not ask very good questions as my heart sank and my mind went blank when he said it definitely was a solid and not a cyst. The first comment he made was that it "could be" a fibroandenoma.  But it was "a little atypical."  I wish I had asked what was atypical about it, but I didn't.  From my view (which is far from expert), the mass looked round in terms of the shape across the width.  There was definitely some height to it and it seemed mostly rounded, although it came to a slight point in the middle.    Kind of reminded me of a spinning top (like kids play with).  It looked smooth on the surface, although not perfectly so.  It was a solid color with no obvious variances.  The edges appear well-defined to me most of the time, but at certain angles seems to blur - not sure if that was the equipment or a characteristic of the mass.  Man, I really wish I had asked more questions. He then later said "this is what we call a round cancer."  I took him to mean that is what they would call it if it is a cancer, not that he actually thinks it is, but I don't know now.  He seemed to genuinely not know what it is and even said all I know is it is a solid mass of something.  Before I left he said "I am not saying you have cancer" and told me not to get panicked.  But at that point I was the verge of losing it and I think he said it just to settle me down. My mom told me that she and her mother both have fibrocystic breasts.  My grandmother had a very large tumor when she was just one year older than I am that was benign.  I do have painful breasts with my period, which have been worse than usual in the last few months.  This lump seemed to appear out of nowhere right after my period (two months ago) and seemed to get larger after my most recent period - but I could be imagining it.  I am hoping that family history governs here and this is just a hormonal thing.  No real history of breast cancer in my family - just a great aunt who did not get it until she was 92, beat it and is pushing 100 now.  God love her - lol.  Anyway - any positive stores about atypical fibroadenomas out there? or fibrocystic masses that had to be biopsied?  I could use the hope.  I am nervous, weeping wreck and fear I will stay this way until results from my core biopsy which is not scheduled for another 10 days.  Lisa Dx 8/6/2010, IDC, Stage IB, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2010 09:43PM lrr4993 wrote: Thanks brady.  I really appreciate the kind thoughts.  I am laughing at your comment about excessive boob feeling.  My lump has had some pain.  I am not sure if it is the lump itself that is painful or my constant feeling of it.  It has been particularly bad today, which I am sure is a combination of PMS, the examination by the docs yesterday, and my nonstop feeling of it since.  After having a near nervous breakdown this evening, which included bawling hysterically on the phone to my mom and almost passing out from hyperventilation,  I have decided to turn over a new leaf.  No more internet on BC/fibroadenomas/etc.  I have myself so worked up and right now it is all for nothing.  I spent all afternoon today on the internet researching various things that may never even be necessary:  FMLA leave; the job market in case mine is put in jeopardy due to needing to take leave for cancer; insurance coverage issues for cancer; I even checked out options for wigs and fake eyebrows.  Crazy, I know.  And the weird part is that my panic is not really about the disease itself.  I actually feel very positive that, if it is cancer, it is likely very treatable.  My bigger concern is the financial impact this may have and the turning of my life upside down for a year - and the hair loss (this one just kills me).  Those are the things that have me freaked out.     The only time I have felt okay since yesterday was during a meeting this morning which kept me from thinking about this.  I am going to bury myself in work.  That way I have plenty of time banked if, worst case, I have to take some off for treatment.  Best case, bigger bonus this year.  But most importantly, it will keep me occupied. Otherwise I will never make it through the next 2 weeks until the results come back.   Or I may go the xanex route!   For now, however, I am going to take two excedrin PM and hope for sleep.  I am sure part of my hysterics are attributable to sleep deprivation.  Good night!

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2010 09:24PM - edited Dec 27, 2010 09:26PM by lrr4993 Carrol - Tomorrow will be 4 weeks from my last CTx4.  Because I did not lose all my hair, it is difficult to tell about regrowth.  However, I had my mom inspect my scalp this weekend and she said there was a lot of stubble coming in. Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 09:26PM lrr4993 wrote: Renk - I hope you and your mom are doing okay.  I was in her shoes in August and I know it is a tough time.  I was an emotional wreck from the first mention of the need for a biopsy up until the path results from my lumpectomy.  I think hit a second wall of crazy waiting for PET scan results.  The waiting really is the worst part and it does get better.  I was told that here several months ago and found it hard to believe at the time.  They were right. About the lymph node biopsy, as it was explained to me, they harvest the sentinel nodes during surgery and those are tested by a team in the operating room while the surgeon is removing the lump.  If those come back negative, then that is the end of the node removal.  If they come back positive, then they pull more for testing.  I was told that the results during surgery are about 95% reliable, meaning that only in 5% of cases do they later find positive nodes upon closer inspection.  And in those few cases, what they usually find is only microscopic cells, not tumors, which my doctor said would not be counted as a positive node for the purpose of staging. Good luck to you and your mom in this process.  If you have questions, this is a great place to come as many people here have been through it and are well-researched and informed.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 09:54PM lrr4993 wrote: You would be surprised how often this occurs.  Pharmacists are humans and any time a human is involved human error is possible.  I always make a note of what I was prescribed to compare it to what I get (name, dosage, and frequency), check my bottles before leaving the pharmacy, and compare what the info on the bottle says to the pills (my pharm has instructions on the bottle, ie, this is a pink pill with xxx on the side).  it has only happened to me once - and happened to be during chemo when my mom went to pick up the px.  She is not as careful about it as me and did not notice it was the wrong px until I pointed out.  LOL.  It is rare that these mistakes ever result in any harm, but I have seen near-fatal situations due to pharmacy misfills.  Scary indeed.

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2011 07:40PM - edited Jan 1, 2011 08:41PM by lrr4993 I was stage 1 but with a very aggressive tumor, so chemo was recommended for me.  However, because it was stage 1, my onco gave me the choice between ACx4 Tx4 (more aggressive and her rec if I had been node positive) or TC x4 (aggressive, but not quite at the level of the other).  I chose the TC, primarily because of the risk of heart damage from adriamycin.  For me, TC was a breeze.  I had few SEs during treatment and no SEs after treatment.  I really did not want to do it at the time, but am glad I did it now.

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 12:24PM lrr4993 wrote: I never buzzed mine so can't answer your question, but the post about little hairs in the collar reminded me of a funny story about my hair loss experience.  It started to come out on a tuesday - exactly 14 days after treatment as I was told.  For the first three days it was shedding, but only slightly more than it normally did - I had a TON of hair and have always shedded more than the average person. By thurs I was afraid to do my usual styling of my naturally curling hair which involved blowing drying it out straight with a round brush.  I was worried the brush would pull out the hair, so I let it dry naturally . . . lots of curls.  By friday morning, I was pretty sure the next shampoo was going to result in enough hair loss that it would be noticeable so I decided not to wash it.  I was trying to hold out until the weekend to switch over to the wig.  I remember I was wearing this cowl neck sweater at work that day.  I kept feeling this kind of heavy feeling in it and I finally reached back and felt what it was - a lot of my hair had fallen out and had slid down and matted in the curl so there was this weird sort of clump of hair all along the bottom edge of my hair, resting in the cowl neck.  LOL.  I immediately went home for the day and took a shower.  It was so matted that I had to just cut it off - I could not get the knots out and the more I tried the more hair that came out. It is funny to think back on, although at the time I was bawling.

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2011 07:54PM - edited Nov 23, 2011 07:57PM by lrr4993 Leesa - I did have a specific day - I did tuesday infusions and the tired/achey always started late evening on fridays and ended by noon sunday.  It was like clockwork.  I slept nearly non-stop during that time.  After that, I did have about 2 days where I would get breathless if I exerted myself too much, which I assume was due to anemia and my blood counts plummeting.  Other than that and of course the hair loss, I had no side effects at all. About the nausea meds, I was given zofran and compazine at first.  I have read that they do not give emend at first because it is so expensive and some insurance companies will not pay for it unless the lesser drugs fail.  I do not do nauseua very well and was not willing to "wait and see how I do" as my onco's nurse insisted when I started to freak out the week before chemo about not having emend.  Probably overkill on my part, but I ended up calling my nurse navigator (not the onco nurse who always just said no) and told her to get me a px for emend by 5:00 that day or I was moving to another oncology group (I am in atlanta and had several choices; this may not work in a smaller community  :)  ).  I got my px.  I was told I was overmedicated but did not care.  I would rather have too much and never be sick.  I don't mean to scare you, but there is no way I would have been okay with what your doctor has given you.

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2012 12:50PM lrr4993 wrote: I had the same 2 choices.  My tumor was slightly larger than yours at just under 2 cm.  I chose TCx4.  Adriamycin runs the risk of heart damage that was not worth the difference in benefit to me.  Also, my onco (who was leading a TN study at one of the top cancer centers) told me that they really don't know if one is better than the other because there has been no comparison study. You should know that there are reported instances of permanent hair loss with TC.  I did not experience it other than one very small spot on one eyebrow, but other have had perm hair loss on their heads.  There are threads about it somewhere on here.

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2011 08:05PM lrr4993 wrote: Vivie - the information available on the web is overwhelming. I am sure if you wanted to post info from your path report, you will get plenty of help translating it. I am not familiar with the "porous" reference, but hopefully someone else is. Generally speaking, the signature lines are diagnosis details. Date of diagnosis; type of cancer; size; stage (a way to categorize how far it has spread); grade (measure of aggressiveness); number of positive lymph nodes/ number of nodes examined; and histology (what is driving the cancer to grow, if known).

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 10:32PM lrr4993 wrote: My understanding is that local recurrance varies depending on the type of BC and other factors.  I am triple negative, which I understand does not tend to recur locally, although there certainly are exceptions to that.  People who are BRCA positive have increased risk of local recurrance.  I am sure there are other factors too.   I did a lumpectomy.  There was never even any discussion of a mastectomy with me other than that it may be a possibility if I was BRCA positive, which I was not.   Re the PET, I do not know the details, but I am sure it probably sees things that an MRI may miss.  Most doctors do not do either for stage one.  I got a PET, but only because I insisted for my own piece of mind.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 07:43PM - edited Jun 1, 2011 07:43PM by lrr4993 Chrys - The wire insertion for me was completely painless. . . I did not feel a thing.  They numb you beforehand, so the only pain was the little prick from the needle for numbing. I did not realize they did this until I got to the hospital for the surgery.  I had spent most of my time worrying about pain from the dye injection, which I read was bad, but it turned out mine too was done while I was under anesthesia.  I am glad I did not know about this ahead of time. One tip - do not look down while they are doing it.  I looked down while she was checking imaging for proper placement.  There were two huge pieces (several inches long) of wire sticking out of my breast.  No blood or gore, but still creepy looking.     Good luck. I know everyone has different experiences, but I found the lumpectomy and SNB to be very easy.  If it had not been for the exhaustion from the anesthesia, I would have been back to work the next day.  I never even filled my px for painkillers - just needed a couple of advil for the first day after the surgery.

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2011 07:46PM lrr4993 wrote: Annie - I do know how good it is to hear that!  I was completely terrified of this chemo because of the nightmare threads on this board about it.  I almost backed out I was so scared.  I was shocked how easy it was.  Of course, some people have a hard time, but some don't.  A few tips . . . not sure if they worked for me or if I was just lucky, but this is what I did: *  chew on ice chips to control mouth/taste issues *  frozen peas/bags of ice on your fingers and toes to prevent nail damage *  drink as much water as you can stand . . . I drank 3-4 2 liter bottles a day the day of treatment and for three days after *   Again, get emend.  I had to threaten to change oncos to get it from the start, but I got it. I never did the neulasta shot.  My once gives them only on an as needed basis and I never needed them.  My blood counts rebounds very well each time.  She said most women my age (40) don't really need them.  I think that is part of why it was so easy for me . . . from what I read, the neulasta shots are as bad or worse than the chemo.  But it seems most oncos give them as a matter of course. If you have any questions, feel free to message me!

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 08:58PM - edited Jan 28, 2011 08:59PM by lrr4993 I had two US biopsies.  Neither caused any pain during the procedure.  I actually found it fascinating - you can watch it on the monitor as they are doing it.  The first one caused some bruising but was not bad.  I had it on short notice and had taken aleve for a few days prior, so it bled more than it should have.  If yours is planned, they will tell you to stay away from stuff like that to prevent bleeding.  I think that is why it was more sore.  The second one was completely painless.  both were no big deal. I know this sounds strange and I did not believe it when it was told to me, but waiting for the biopsy results is the most stressful part of all this.  I was a wreck - much more so than I was after being told it was cancer.  Weird I know, but it is true.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 10:24PM lrr4993 wrote: That is a very tough decision.  I agree that quality of life is a big concern for your mother.  My grandmother was diagnosed with stage 4 ovarian cancer.   For reasons that are not entirely clear to me, she did do chemo.  It made her deathly ill and she spent the last week of her life in the hospital trying to control the chemo SEs.  In retrospect, I wish the decision had been made otherwise as she was not feeling too bad before chemo and probably could have enjoyed some quality time at home with family and friends. That said, I have a great aunt who was diagnosed with BC in her early 80s.  I don't know the stage (I am guessing she was not stage 4) but she did do chemo.  She did well on chemo and lived to her mid 90s.   She was otherwise in good health though. Good luck with his difficult decision.

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2011 09:11PM lrr4993 wrote: Kasi - I just stumbled on this thread and was struck by how much you remind me of myself around the time of my diagnosis. I just had to post.  I had the same "its probably a cyst" convo that was "definitely not a cyst" once we did an ultrasound.  Like you, before I even had a diagnosis I knew all about penguin cold caps.  LOL.  I even had my wig picked out before diagnosis!  I had similar looking hair - long, dark, naturally curly (yours looks like it anyway) that, although I have complained about it all my life, the thought of losing it just killed me.  Yes, that was my biggest concern - what will I do without hair and how am going to go to work or anywhere else like that.  I was a mess before and after diagnosis.  I cried more than I have ever cried in my life.  I am not quite as young as you but still on the young side for BC (I was diagnosed 2 weeks after my 40th bday) and it is such a hard blow.  I was just like you - very happy, things were going great, and boom - breast cancer.  Never saw that one coming.  WTF?! Everything you are feeling is very very normal.  I know it does not seem like it now, but believe me when I tell you it will get better.  I was told that when I was where you are and did not believe it, but it is true that this is the worst part.  I did a lumpectomy first, so my course of treatment was a bit different, but by the time I got to chemo, I was emotionally fairly solid.  Chemo turned out to be a breeze.  It really did.  The only time I missed from work was my infusion days.  I had only one "bad" day after each treatment which consisted of muscle aches and a lot of sleeping - like having the flu.  Otherwise, I was fine.   By far, the hair is the worst part.  I cried for hours when it fell out.  I remember thinking that night that I was going to hang sheets over all of the mirrors because I could not stand to look at myself.  But you know what, by the next day I was over it and I never cried again over my hair.  I got a great wig that I love and that looked a lot like my own hair.  Really, it was my hair but better . . . only 2 minutes to get ready in the mornings and no humidity frizz!  It helped tremendously.  Other than a select few, no one even knows I had cancer.  You are stronger than you know.  Hang in there and feel free to message me with any questions or if you just want to vent.  And one last thing - see how things go before you decide on your trip.  I had a huge vacation planned for last fall that I cancelled because I thought, like you, that I could not work it in with all the time off for chemo.  Turns out chemo did not involve much time off and I could have taken my vacation.  And if you do have to cancel it, just move it until the spring.  The Keys are spectacular in the spring (I am a florida girl and did spring break there a couple of times in college).  I just got back from my postponed vacation two weeks ago and I think it actually worked out better because the areas we visited were so beautiful with spring flowers and perfect spring weather.
Posts.Title: Not Diagnosed Yet But Radiologist Not Optimistic Kasi redroks2

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2013 07:28PM lrr4993 wrote: Personally, I probably would opt out of any significant medical procedures at that age. However, I have a great aunt who was diagnosed with breast cancer just shy of 90. She had surgery and chemo - I am not sure if radiation or other treatments. She sailed through and lived another 10 years, dying from something other than cancer. She was otherwise in very good health. Good luck to your aunt!
Posts.Title: 90 yo just diagnosed with IPC--what to do? bronxville Beesie

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2011 12:48PM lrr4993 wrote: Is this where they test the tumor after biopsy to see what chemo it responds to? If so, I was told these are not considered reliable because the chemo works differently in you body than outside of it. Personally, I find it incredible that there is no way to do this sort of test with reliability. At the very least, it seems more reliable than the "who knows if it is working" approach used for post surgery chemo. I would be curious to learn more.
Posts.Title: Any survivors with experience with chemo cell-death assays? NKCell babs6287

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2010 08:00PM lrr4993 wrote: Tell me about it.  I have never been so scared in my life.  Found a lump about 6 weeks ago.  It seemed to appear out of nowhere.  I finally got in today to see the doctor.  She thought it was a cyst and recommended coming back in a couple of weeks for a mammogram/sonogram.  I insisted on at least the sonogram today as I was a wreck.  It is definitely not a cyst.  It is a 2 cm solid mass.  The radiologist was noncommital on whether it is a fibroandenoma or cancer.   He said it could be the former, but it was "a little atypical."  Lympnodes were normal on the sonogram, which is a positive but I am not sure it means all that much at this point.  Now scheduled for a needle biopsy in 10 days.  I don't think I can wait til then.  Going to call another facility in the morning to see if they can work me in earlier. I have done nothing all day but cry and research both fibroandenomas and breast cancer on the internet.  I feel nauseous from the anxiety.
